Chapter 10, Part 3: The Bodhisattva King of Dignified Virtue of Universal Illumination
Furthermore, good sons!

All ordinary beings, although they protect their bodies well, still give rise to three kinds of evil thoughts in their minds. For this reason, although they cut off afflictions and attain rebirth in the realm of neither perception nor non-perception, they still fall back into the three evil destinies.
Good sons!
It is like a person crossing the great ocean, about to reach the other shore, but drowning and dying in the water.
Ordinary beings are also like this. They are about to end the three realms of existence, but fall back into the three evil paths.
Why is this?
Because they lack wholesome thoughts.
What are wholesome thoughts?
They are the six recollections.

The wholesome thoughts of ordinary beings are weak, while their unwholesome thoughts are rampant. Because their wholesome thoughts are weak, their thoughts of wisdom are meager. Because their thoughts of wisdom are meager, they increase their defilements.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with the pure eye of wisdom, see the faults of the three kinds of evil thoughts, and know that these three kinds of evil thoughts have various harms, and always act as the enemy of the three vehicles for sentient beings.

The causes and conditions of the three kinds of evil thoughts cause countless ordinary sentient beings to not see the Buddha-nature, and for countless eons they give rise to inverted thoughts, saying that the World-Honored Buddha is impermanent, blissful, self, and that there is only one purity, and that the TathÄgata ultimately enters nirvÄá¹‡a.
All sentient beings are impermanent, without bliss, without self, and without purity. Because of inverted thoughts, they say there is permanence, bliss, self, and purity.

There is actually only one vehicle, but because of inverted thoughts they say there are three vehicles. The one true path is truly not false, but because of inverted thoughts they say there is no one truth.
These three kinds of evil thoughts are always reprimanded by the Buddhas and bodhisattvas. These three kinds of evil thoughts always harm oneself and may also harm others.
If one has these three kinds of thoughts, all evils will always follow. These three kinds of thoughts are the three bonds that bind sentient beings to endless birth and death.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always contemplate the three kinds of thoughts in this way.

Sometimes, for some reason, bodhisattvas should give rise to thoughts of desire but remain silent and not accept them. It is like a handsome and clean person who does not accept any filth and impurity;
like a red-hot iron ball that no one can accept;
like a brahmin who does not accept beef;
like a full person who does not accept bad food;
like a wheel-turning king who does not sit on the same bed as any outcasts.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas despise the three kinds of thoughts and do not accept or savor them in the same way.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattvas contemplate:
'Sentient beings know that I am a good field of blessings. How can I accept these evil dharmas?'
If one receives evil thoughts, one is not worthy to be a field of blessings for sentient beings.
I do not say that I am a good field of blessings, but sentient beings see my appearance and say that I am.
If I now give rise to such evil thoughts, I will be deceiving all sentient beings.
Because of deception in the past, I have been wandering in birth and death for immeasurable eons and have fallen into the three evil paths.
If I were to accept the offerings of faith with an evil mind, all gods, humans, and those with the five supernatural powers would know and rebuke me.
If I were to accept the offerings of faith with evil thoughts, it would cause the donors to have little reward or no reward at all.
If I were to accept the offerings of donors with an evil mind, I would become an enemy to the donors.
All donors always think of me as their child. How could I deceive them and give rise to enmity?
Why is it so?
Because it would cause the donors to not receive rewards or to receive few rewards.
I always call myself a renunciant. A renunciant should not give rise to evil. If one gives rise to evil, then one is not a renunciant.
A renunciant's body and speech should be in accord. If they are not in accord, then one is not a renunciant.

I have abandoned my parents, brothers, wife, children, relatives, friends, and acquaintances, and left the household life to cultivate the Way. This is precisely the time to cultivate wholesome thoughts, not the time to cultivate unwholesome thoughts.
It is like a person who enters the ocean seeking treasures, but instead of taking real treasures, he takes quartz.
It is also like a person who abandons wonderful music and plays in filth.ğŸ”½It is like abandoning a precious woman and having relations with a maid.
It is like abandoning golden utensils and using earthenware bowls.ğŸ”½It is like abandoning nectar and taking poisonous medicine.
It is like abandoning one's relatives and good doctors, and following an evil doctor to seek and take medicine.
I am also like this, abandoning the great teacher, the Tathagata, the World-Honored One, the sweet nectar of the Dharma, and instead following the various evil thoughts of Mara, the enemy.
The human body is difficult to obtain, like the udumbara flower, and I have now obtained it;
The Tathagata is difficult to encounter, more so than the udumbara flower, and I have now encountered him;
The pure Dharma treasure is difficult to see and hear, and I have now heard it.
It is like a blind turtle encountering a floating wooden yoke.

Human life does not linger, passing by faster than a mountain stream. Even if I exist today, it is difficult to be assured of tomorrow. How can I indulge my mind and allow it to dwell in evil dharmas?
Youthful appearance does not linger, like a galloping horse. How can I rely on it and give rise to arrogance?
It is like an evil ghost seeking people's faults. The four great ghosts are also like this. They always come to seek my faults. How can I allow evil thoughts to arise?
It is like an old house, about to collapse;
My life is also like this. How can I give rise to evil?
I am called a Å›ramaá¹‡a, and a Å›ramaá¹‡a is called one who awakens to goodness;
I have now given rise to unwholesome thoughts, how can I still be called a Å›ramaá¹‡a?
I am called one who has left the household life, and one who has left the household life is called one who cultivates the good path;
I now practice evil, how can I still be called one who has left the household life?
I am now called a true brÄhmaá¹‡a, and a brÄhmaá¹‡a is called one who cultivates pure conduct;
I now engage in impure and evil thoughts, how can I still be called a brÄhmaá¹‡a?
I am now also called a ká¹£atriya of the great clan, and a ká¹£atriya is able to eliminate enemies;
I am now unable to eliminate evil enemies, how can I still be called a ká¹£atriya?
I am called a bhiká¹£u, and a bhiká¹£u is called one who destroys afflictions;
I now do not destroy the afflictions of evil thoughts, how can I still be called a bhiká¹£u?
There are six situations in the world that are difficult to encounter, I have now obtained them, how can I allow evil thoughts to dwell in my mind?
What are the six?

First, Buddhas are difficult to encounter in the world; second, the true Dharma is difficult to hear; third, it is difficult to give rise to fear; fourth, it is difficult to be born in a central country; fifth, it is difficult to obtain a human body; sixth, it is difficult to have complete faculties.
These six things are difficult to obtain, yet one has already obtained them. Therefore, one should not give rise to evil thoughts.

' At that time, the Bodhisattva practiced this MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra and always diligently observed these evil thoughts. All ordinary people do not see the faults of such evil thoughts, and therefore they accept the three kinds of thoughts, which is called accepting defilements.

The Bodhisattva, having seen this, does not accept, does not cling to, abandons, and does not protect. Relying on the Eightfold Noble Path, he pushes them away and cuts them off. Therefore, the Bodhisattva has no accepting defilements. How can it be said that the TathÄgata has defilements?
For this reason, the World-Honored TathÄgata is not defiled.
Moreover, good man!

Ordinary people, if they encounter physical or mental suffering and give rise to various evils, if they get sick in body or mind, causing body, speech, and mind to commit various evils, because of committing evils they revolve in the three paths and experience all kinds of suffering.
Why is it so?
Because ordinary people lack mindfulness and wisdom, they give rise to various defilements, which are called the defilements of mindfulness.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always contemplate:

'From beginningless eons in the past, I have created various evils with this body and mind. Because of these causes and conditions, I have been transmigrating in the cycle of birth and death, in the three evil destinies, experiencing all kinds of suffering, causing me to be far from the right path of the three vehicles.'
Because of these evil causes and conditions, the bodhisattva gives rise to great fear towards his own body and mind, abandons various evils, and heads towards the good path.
Good man!

It is like a king who puts four poisonous snakes in a box and has a man take care of them, feeding and raising them, bathing and grooming them, saying, If one of the snakes becomes angry, I will punish you by beheading you in the city.
At that time, the man, hearing the king's strict order, was frightened and abandoned the box to flee.
The king then sent five caá¹‡á¸Älas with drawn swords to follow behind him. The man looked back and saw the five people behind him, so he fled even faster.
At that time, the five people, using evil means, hid the swords they were carrying and secretly sent one person, pretending to be a close friend, to say to him,
You should come back.
The man did not believe it and went to a village to hide himself.

After entering the village, he looked into the houses but did not see anyone. He grabbed the pots and vessels, all of which were empty with nothing in them. Since he did not see anyone and could not find anything, he sat on the ground and heard a voice in the sky saying:
'Alas, my friend!
This place is empty and desolate, with no inhabitants.
Tonight, there will be six great thieves coming. If you encounter them, your life will not be spared. What will you do to escape them?'
At that time, the man's fear increased even more, and he left again.
On the way, he encountered a river with swift currents, with no boats or rafts. Due to his fear, he gathered various grasses and wood to make a raft.
He further thought:
'If I stay here, I will be harmed by the poisonous snake, the five candalas, the one pretending to be friendly, and the six great thieves.
If I cross this river, the raft may not be reliable and I may drown in the water.
It is better to die in the water than to be harmed by the snake and thieves.'
He then pushed the grass raft into the water, placed himself on it, supported himself with his hands and feet, and crossed the river against the current.
Having reached the other shore, they are at peace and free from trouble, their minds are at ease, and their fears are eliminated.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who hear and uphold the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra contemplate the body as a box, and the earth, water, fire, and wind as the four poisonous snakes - the poison of sight, the poison of touch, the poison of breath, and the poison of bite - all sentient beings encounter these four poisons and lose their lives because of them.

Sentient beings' four great elements are also like this. Either seeing is evil, or touching is evil, or breathing is evil, or biting is evil. For these reasons, they stay far away from many wholesome things.
Furthermore, good man!ğŸ”½Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the four poisonous snakes having four kinds of lineages, namely ká¹£atriya, brÄhmaá¹‡a, vaiÅ›ya, and Å›Å«dra.

These four great snake-like elements are also like this. They have four kinds of natures, the nature of solidity, the nature of wetness, the nature of heat, and the nature of movement. Therefore, bodhisattvas contemplate these four great elements as having the same nature as the four poisonous snakes.
Next, good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate these four great elements as four poisonous snakes.
How do they contemplate?
These four poisonous snakes always watch for an opportunity in people, thinking, When will they look at me?ğŸ”½When will they touch me?
When will they step on me?
When will they bite me?
The four poisonous snakes are also like this, always watching for an opportunity to harm sentient beings.
If one is killed by the four snakes, one will never reach the three evil destinies;
If one is killed by the four great elements, one will definitely reach the three evil destinies, without a doubt.
Although these four poisonous snakes are tended to, they still want to kill people;
The four great elements are also like this. Although they are always taken care of, they always lead people to create various evils.
If one of these four poisonous snakes becomes angry, it can kill a person;
The nature of the four great elements is also like this. If one of the great elements goes awry, it can also harm a person.
Although these four poisonous snakes are in the same place, their four minds are each different;
The four poisonous snakes of the four elements are also like this. Although they are in the same place, their natures are each different.
Although these four poisonous snakes are respected, they are difficult to be close to;
The four poisonous snakes of the four elements are also like this. Although they are respected, they are also difficult to be close to.
If these four poisonous snakes harm a person, there may be Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others who can cure them with spells and medicine;
The four elements kill a person. Even if there are Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others with divine spells and good medicine, they cannot cure it.
It is like a person who delights in himself. Hearing the foul and disgusting smell of the four poisonous snakes, he then stays far away;
The buddhas and bodhisattvas are also like this. Hearing the foul smell of the four elements, they then stay far away.
At that time, the bodhisattva further contemplated the four poisonous snakes, gave rise to great fear, turned his back and ran away, and cultivated the eightfold noble path.
The five types of candÄla are the five aggregates.
How do bodhisattvas contemplate the five aggregates as being like candÄlas?
CandÄlas can always cause people to be separated from their loved ones and brought together with their enemies.
The five aggregates are also like this, causing people to greedily approach unwholesome dharmas and to distance themselves from all pure and wholesome dharmas.
Furthermore, good man!
CandÄlas adorn themselves with various weapons, such as swords, shields, bows, arrows, armor, and spears, which can harm people.
The five aggregates are also like this. They firmly adorn themselves with various afflictions, harming ignorant people and causing them to fall into various existences.
Good man!ğŸ”½CandÄlas can harm those who offend them.
The five aggregates are also like this. They always harm people based on the offenses created by the bonds [of existence].
For this reason, bodhisattvas deeply contemplate the five aggregates as being like candÄlas.
Furthermore, a bodhisattva observes the five aggregates as being like a caá¹‡á¸Äla:
A caá¹‡á¸Äla person has no compassionate heart, harming both enemies and friends;
The five aggregates are also like this, having no compassionate heart, harming both good and evil.
Just as a caá¹‡á¸Äla torments all people;
The five aggregates are also like this, with all afflictions always tormenting all sentient beings in the cycle of birth and death.
Therefore, a bodhisattva observes the five aggregates as being like a caá¹‡á¸Äla.
Furthermore, a bodhisattva observes the five aggregates as being like a caá¹‡á¸Äla:
A caá¹‡á¸Äla person always harbors a harmful mind;
The five aggregates are also like this, always harboring the harmful mind of various bonds.
Just as a person without feet or a sword or attendants should know that they will certainly be killed by a caá¹‡á¸Äla;
Sentient beings are also like this, without feet or a sword or attendants, they will be robbed and harmed by the five aggregates.
The feet are called precepts, the sword is called wisdom, and the attendants are called good spiritual friends. Without these three things, one will be harmed by the five aggregates.
Therefore, the bodhisattva views the five aggregates as like a caá¹‡á¸Äla.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes that the five aggregates are worse than a caá¹‡á¸Äla.
Why is it so?

If sentient beings are killed by the five caá¹‡á¸Älas, they will not fall into hell, but those killed by the aggregates will fall into hell. For this reason, the bodhisattva views the aggregates as worse than a caá¹‡á¸Äla.
Having made this observation, he makes the vow, saying:
'I would rather be near a caá¹‡á¸Äla for my whole life than be near the five aggregates for even a short time.
A caá¹‡á¸Äla can only harm foolish people in the desire realm;
This thief of the five aggregates pervasively harms sentient beings in the three realms.
A caá¹‡á¸Äla can only kill those who have committed offenses;
These five aggregates are thieves. They do not ask whether sentient beings have faults or not, and they can all harm them.
Chandalas do not harm the old, women, or children;
These five aggregates are thieves. They do not ask whether sentient beings are old, young, or women, and they harm everyone.

Therefore, bodhisattvas deeply observe that these aggregates are worse than chandalas. Therefore, they make vows, thinking, It is better to be near a chandala until the end of one's life, than to be near the five aggregates for even a short time.
Furthermore, good man!ğŸ”½Chandalas only harm others, not themselves;
The five aggregates are thieves that harm both themselves and others, worse than chandalas.
Chandalas can be bribed with kind words, money, or valuables to let one go;
The five aggregates are not like this. One cannot bribe them with kind words, money, or valuables to let one go.
Chandalas do not necessarily kill all the time, in the four seasons;
The five aggregates are not like this, constantly harming all sentient beings in every thought.
The caá¹‡á¸Äla only stays in one place, and one can avoid them;
The five aggregates are not like this, pervading everywhere, with no place to escape.
Although the caá¹‡á¸Äla harms people, they do not follow after them;
The five aggregates are not like this, killing sentient beings and following after them without separation.
Therefore, a bodhisattva would rather remain with a caá¹‡á¸Äla until the end of their life, but cannot be with the five aggregates even for a short while.
A wise person uses skillful means to escape the five aggregates.

Skillful means refers to the eightfold noble path, the six pÄramitÄs, and the four immeasurable minds. Using these skillful means, one attains liberation, and body and mind are not harmed by the five aggregates.
Why is this?
The body is like vajra, and the mind is like space. Therefore, body and mind are difficult to destroy.
For this reason, the bodhisattva observes that the aggregates are replete with various unwholesome dharmas, and gives rise to great fear, cultivating the eightfold noble path.
It is also like that person who is afraid of the four poisonous snakes and five bandits, and goes on his way without looking back.
The so-called 'pretending friend' is called craving and love.

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva deeply observes the bonds of craving, like an enemy pretending to be a friend. If one knows the truth, then there is nothing that can be done. If one is unable to know, one will certainly be harmed.

Craving and love are also like this. If one knows its nature, then it cannot cause sentient beings to transmigrate in the suffering of birth and death. If one does not know, one will revolve through the six destinies and experience various sufferings.
Why is this?
Because the illness of love is difficult to abandon.

Like an enemy pretending to be a friend, it is difficult to get rid of. The one who pretends to be an enemy always seeks an opportunity to cause separation from what is loved and to bring together what is hated.
Desire is also like this, causing people to distance themselves from all wholesome dharmas and approach all unwholesome dharmas.
For this reason, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas deeply contemplate desire as an enemy pretending to be a friend.
Because of seeing and not seeing, hearing and not hearing, like ordinary people who see the faults of birth and death, although they have wisdom, because of delusion they later do not see again.
The Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas are also like this, although they see they do not see, although they hear they do not hear.
Why is this?
Because of the mind of desire.
Why is this?
Because of seeing the faults of birth and death, they cannot quickly reach supreme perfect enlightenment.
For this reason, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate this desire-bond as an enemy pretending to be a friend.
What is meant by the appearance of an enemy pretending to be a friend?

Like an enemy, it is not real but pretends to be real, cannot be befriended but pretends to be friendly, is actually unwholesome but pretends to be wholesome, and is actually unlovable but pretends to be lovable.
Why is this?
Because it always seeks an opportunity to harm people.

Love is also like this. It is always unreal for sentient beings but pretends to be real, is not friendly but pretends to be friendly, is not wholesome but pretends to be wholesome, and is not lovable but pretends to be lovable. It always deceives everyone, causing them to revolve in birth and death.
For this reason, bodhisattvas view love as an enemy pretending to be a friend.
An enemy pretending to be a friend is only seen in body and speech, not in the mind. Therefore, it can deceive;
Love is also like this. It is only for deception and cannot be truly obtained. Therefore, it can confuse all sentient beings.
An enemy pretending to be a friend has a beginning and an end and is easy to avoid;
Love is not like this. It has no beginning and no end and is difficult to avoid.
Deceitful friends, if far away, are difficult to know, but if near, they are easy to know.
Love is not like this. Even if near, it is still difficult to know, let alone if far away.
For this reason, the bodhisattva views love as surpassing deceitful friends.

All sentient beings, because of the bonds of love, are far from great nirvana, close to birth and death, far from permanence, bliss, self, and purity, and close to impermanence, suffering, no-self, and impurity. For this reason, I have said in various sutras that they are the three defilements.
Regarding present matters, because of ignorance, one does not see the faults and is unable to abandon love, which is like a deceitful friend. It will ultimately not harm the wise person.

Therefore, the bodhisattva deeply observes this love and gives rise to great fear. Cultivating the eightfold noble path is like that person who fears the four poisonous snakes, the five cÄá¹‡á¸Äla, and the one deceitful friend, and does not look back while on the road.
The empty village is none other than the six sense bases.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the six internal sense bases as empty and nonexistent, like an empty village. Just as that frightened person, after entering the village, does not see a single inhabitant anywhere, and searches through all the pots and containers, but finds not a single thing,

the bodhisattvas are also like this. They contemplate the six sense bases as empty and nonexistent, and do not see the reality of a single thing in sentient beings. Therefore, the bodhisattvas contemplate the six internal sense bases as empty and nonexistent, like that empty village.
Good man!
That empty village, when seen from afar by a group of thieves, never gives rise to the thought of emptiness.

Ordinary beings are also like this. They do not give rise to the thought of emptiness towards the village of the six sense bases. Because they are unable to give rise to the thought of emptiness, they revolve in birth and death, experiencing immeasurable suffering.
Good man!

When the group of thieves arrives, they then give rise to the thought of emptiness. The bodhisattvas are also like this. They contemplate these six sense bases and always give rise to the thought of emptiness. Because they give rise to the thought of emptiness, they do not revolve in birth and death, experiencing suffering.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are always free from delusion regarding these six sense bases. Because they are free from delusion, they do not continue to revolve in birth and death.

Furthermore, good sons!ğŸ”½Just as a group of thieves entering this empty village can find peace and comfort, so too are the thieves of afflictions able to find peace and comfort by entering these six sense bases.
Just as thieves dwelling in an empty village have nothing to fear, so too are the thieves of afflictions able to dwell in these six sense bases without fear.

Just as that empty village is the dwelling place of lions, tigers, wolves, and various other ferocious beasts, so too are these inner six sense bases the dwelling place of all the running beasts of afflictions.
Therefore, bodhisattvas deeply contemplate that the six sense bases are empty and nonexistent, and are purely the dwelling places of all that is unwholesome.
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate that the inner six sense bases are empty and nonexistent, like that empty village.
Why is it so?

Because they are false and unreal, empty and nonexistent, they give rise to the thought of existence. In reality there is no bliss, yet they give rise to the thought of bliss. In reality there is no person, yet they give rise to the thought of person.
Only a wise person can know this and attain its true reality.
Furthermore, good man!
Like an empty village, sometimes there are people, sometimes there are no people;
The six sense bases are not like this, they are always devoid of people.
Why is it so?
Because their nature is always empty, it is known by the wise, not seen by the eyes.

Therefore, bodhisattvas contemplate the six internal sense bases, which are full of many enemies and harms, and cultivate the eightfold noble path without rest, just like that person who is afraid of the four poisonous snakes, the five cÄá¹‡á¸Äla, the one pretending to be kind, and the six great thieves, and flees onto the right path.
The six great thieves are the external six sense objects.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas view these six sense objects as the six great thieves.
Why is this?
Because they are able to plunder all wholesome dharmas.
Just as the six great thieves are able to plunder the wealth and treasures of all the people, these six sense objects are also like this, able to plunder the wholesome wealth of all sentient beings.

Just as the six great thieves, if they enter someone's house, are able to plunder all the current possessions of the household, not discriminating between good and bad, causing the very wealthy to suddenly become impoverished,

these six sense objects are also like this. If they enter someone's faculties, they are able to plunder all wholesome dharmas. Once the wholesome dharmas are exhausted, one becomes impoverished, destitute, and a icchantika. Therefore, bodhisattvas carefully observe the six sense objects as if they were the six great thieves.
Moreover, good man!
Just as the six great thieves, when wishing to plunder people, must rely on insiders. If there are no insiders, they will turn back in the middle.

The six sense objects are also like this. In order to plunder wholesome dharmas, they must rely on the internal existence of the characteristics of sentient beings' knowledge and vision, permanence, bliss, self, purity, non-emptiness, and so forth.
If internally there are no such characteristics, then the evil thieves of the six sense objects will not be able to plunder all wholesome dharmas.

The wise person internally has no such characteristics, but ordinary beings do. Therefore, the six sense objects always come and plunder the wealth of wholesome dharmas, because they are not well protected and are plundered by them.

Protection is called wisdom. The wise person is able to well guard against them, and therefore is not plundered. Therefore, the Bodhisattva views the six sense objects as being no different from the six great thieves.
Moreover, good man!
Like the six great thieves who can cause people's bodies and minds to suffer;
The six sense objects are also like this. They always cause sentient beings' bodies and minds to suffer.
The six great thieves can only plunder people's present wealth;
These six sense objects are thieves who constantly plunder the good wealth of sentient beings in the three times.
The six great thieves are joyful at night;
The six sense objects are also like this, finding joy in the darkness of ignorance.
These six great thieves can only be stopped by the king;
The six sense objects are also like this, only Buddhas and Bodhisattvas can stop them.
These six great thieves, when wanting to rob, do not discriminate between handsome and ugly, noble and humble, intelligent and ignorant, wealthy and poor;
The six sense objects are also like this, wanting to plunder good dharmas without discriminating between handsome and ugly, up to poor and humble.
These six great thieves, even if the king cuts off their hands and feet, still cannot make their minds stop;
The six sense objects are also like this, even if srotÄpannas, saká¹›dÄgÄmins, and anÄgÄmins cut off their hands and feet, they still cannot make them stop plundering good dharmas.
Just as a brave and strong person can subdue these six great thieves, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas are also like this, able to subdue the six sense objects as evil thieves.
It is like a person with many relatives and clans, whose family is prosperous, not being robbed by those six thieves;
sentient beings are also like this, having good spiritual friends, not being robbed by the six sense objects as evil thieves.
These six great thieves, if they see people's possessions, can steal and rob;
the six sense objects are not like this, whether seen, known, heard, smelled, touched, or perceived, they can all rob.
The six great thieves can only rob the wealth of people in the desire realm, and cannot rob the form and formless realms;
the six sense objects as evil thieves are not like this, they can rob all the good treasures of the three realms.

Therefore, the Bodhisattva contemplates the six sense objects as being worse than those six thieves. Having made this contemplation, he cultivates the Eightfold Noble Path, going straight forward without turning back.
It is like that frightened person, fearing the four poisonous snakes, the five bandits, the one false friend, and the six great thieves, abandoning the empty village and setting out on the road.
The road encountering a river is the afflictions.
How do bodhisattvas contemplate these afflictions as being like a great river?
Just as that swift river can carry away a fragrant elephant;
The swift river of afflictions is also like this, able to carry away pratyekabuddhas. Therefore, bodhisattvas deeply contemplate the afflictions as being like a swift river.
It is difficult to reach the bottom, so it is called a river;
The sides cannot be reached, so it is called great. Within it there are many kinds of evil fish. The great river of afflictions is also like this.
Only Buddhas and Bodhisattvas can reach the bottom, so it is called extremely deep.
